You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 466, 808, 481]]<|/det|> - Write your name, centre number and candidate number in the boxes at the top of the page. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 481, 565, 496]]<|/det|> - Write your answer to each question in the space provided. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 497, 482, 512]]<|/det|> - Do not use an erasable pen or correction fluid. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 513, 358, 528]]<|/det|> - Do not write on any bar codes. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 529, 867, 544]]<|/det|> - If additional space is needed, you should use the lined page at the end of this booklet; the question number or numbers must be clearly shown. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 560, 482, 575]]<|/det|> - You should use a calculator where appropriate. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 575, 881, 590]]<|/det|> - You must show all necessary working clearly; no marks will be given for unsupported answers from a calculator. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 605, 854, 620]]<|/det|> - Give non-exact numerical answers correct to 3 significant figures, or 1 decimal place for angles in degrees, unless a different level of accuracy is specified in the question. <|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 669, 214, 680]]<|/det|> # INFORMATION <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 683, 388, 698]]<|/det|> - The total mark for this paper is 75 . <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 698, 730, 714]]<|/det|> - The number of marks for each question or part question is shown in brackets [ ]. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[270, 868, 727, 885]]<|/det|> This document has 20 pages. Any blank pages are indicated.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 74, 918, 91]]<|/det|>
1 The matrix \(\mathbf{M}\) represents the sequence of two transformations in the \(x-y\) plane given by a stretch parallel to the \(x\)-axis, scale factor 14 , followed by a rotation anticlockwise about the origin through angle \(\frac{1}{3} \pi\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 109, 407, 146]]<|/det|>
(a) Show that \(2 \mathbf{M}=\left(\begin{array}{cc}14 & -\sqrt{3} \\ 14 \sqrt{3} & 1\end{array}\right)\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 459, 918, 477]]<|/det|>
(b) Find the equations of the invariant lines, through the origin, of the transformation in the \(x-y\) plane represented by \(\mathbf{M}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 611, 708, 630]]<|/det|>
The unit square \(S\) in the \(x-y\) plane is transformed by \(\mathbf{M}\) onto the rectangle \(P\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 643, 496, 662]]<|/det|>
(c) Find the matrix which transforms \(P\) onto \(S\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 76, 918, 95]]<|/det|>
2 Prove by mathematical induction that \(2025^{n}+47^{n}-2\) is divisible by 46 for all positive integers \(n\) ．［6］

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[433, 74, 565, 89]]<|/det|>
BLANK PAGE

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 76, 617, 96]]<|/det|>
3 The quartic equation \(x^{4}+7 x^{2}+3 x+22=0\) has roots \(\alpha, \beta, \gamma, \delta\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 107, 438, 126]]<|/det|>
(a) Find the value of \(\alpha^{2}+\beta^{2}+\gamma^{2}+\delta^{2}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 570, 438, 588]]<|/det|>
(b) Find the value of \(\alpha^{4}+\beta^{4}+\gamma^{4}+\delta^{4}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 74, 730, 91]]<|/det|>
(c) Use standard results from the list of formulae (MF19) to find the value of

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[306, 91, 690, 138]]<|/det|>
\[
\sum_{r=1}^{10}\left(\left(\alpha^{2}+r\right)^{2}+\left(\beta^{2}+r\right)^{2}+\left(\gamma^{2}+r\right)^{2}+\left(\delta^{2}+r\right)^{2}\right)
\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 76, 788, 96]]<|/det|>
(c) Given that \(v_{r}=x^{w_{r+1}}-x^{w_{r}}\), find the set of values of \(x\) for which the infinite series

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[433, 107, 566, 128]]<|/det|>
\[
v_{1}+v_{2}+v_{3}+\ldots
\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[157, 138, 614, 155]]<|/det|>
is convergent and give the sum to infinity when this exists.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 76, 700, 93]]<|/det|>
5 The plane \(\Pi\) has equation \(\mathbf{r}=2 \mathbf{i}+3 \mathbf{j}-2 \mathbf{k}+\lambda(\mathbf{i}-2 \mathbf{j}-\mathbf{k})+\mu(3 \mathbf{i}+2 \mathbf{j}-2 \mathbf{k})\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 107, 785, 124]]<|/det|>
(a) Find a Cartesian equation of \(\Pi\), giving your answer in the form \(a x+b y+c z=d\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 507, 465, 524]]<|/det|>
The point \(P\) has position vector \(4 \mathbf{i}+2 \mathbf{j}+9 \mathbf{k}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 538, 695, 555]]<|/det|>
(b) Find the position vector of the foot of the perpendicular from \(P\) to \(\Pi\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 427, 507, 447]]<|/det|>
（c）The line \(l\) is parallel to the vector \(3 \mathbf{i}+5 \mathbf{j}-\mathbf{k}\) ．

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 459, 454, 477]]<|/det|>
Find the acute angle between \(l\) and \(\Pi\) ．

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 76, 653, 108]]<|/det|>
6 The curve \(C\) has equation \(y=\frac{x^{2}+a}{x+a}\), where \(a\) is a positive constant.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 115, 489, 134]]<|/det|>
(a) Find the equations of the asymptotes of \(C\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 548, 675, 566]]<|/det|>
(b) Find, in terms of \(a\), the \(x\)-coordinates of the stationary points on \(C\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 74, 680, 91]]<|/det|>
(c) Sketch \(C\), stating the coordinates of any intersections with the axes.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 493, 506, 532]]<|/det|>
(d) Sketch the curve with equation \(y=\left|\frac{x^{2}+a}{x+a}\right|\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 76, 716, 112]]<|/det|>
（e）Find the set of values of \(a\) for which \(\left|\frac{x^{2}+a}{x+a}\right|=a\) has two real solutions．

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[433, 74, 565, 89]]<|/det|>
BLANK PAGE

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 76, 648, 99]]<|/det|>
7 The curve \(C\) has polar equation \(r^{2}=\mathrm{e}^{\sin \theta} \cos \theta\), for \(-\frac{1}{2} \pi \leqslant \theta \leqslant \frac{1}{2} \pi\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 109, 918, 126]]<|/det|>
(a) Find the polar coordinates of the point on \(C\) that is furthest from the pole, giving your answers correct to 3 decimal places.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 523, 918, 545]]<|/det|>
(b) Find the polar coordinates of the point on \(C\) that is furthest from the half-line \(\theta=\frac{1}{2} \pi\), giving your answers correct to 3 decimal places.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 74, 236, 89]]<|/det|>
(c) Sketch \(C\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 505, 750, 522]]<|/det|>
(d) Find the area of the region bounded by \(C\), giving your answer in exact form.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[81, 105, 918, 122]]<|/det|>
If you use the following page to complete the answer to any question, the question number must be clearly shown.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[433, 74, 565, 89]]<|/det|>
